subject: RE: [junit] using junit with an existing testing tool
msgSnippet: I m curious why JUnit doesn t hear the exception.  Unless your test case code is catching it, JUnit will catch it and mark the test as an error.  I suspect
messageBody:
I'm curious why JUnit doesn't "hear" the exception. Unless your test
case code is catching it, JUnit will catch it and mark the test as an
error. I suspect your the code that you wrapped with JUnit is catching
the exception and not re-throwing it.


Todd.

> Hi all,
> Im currently using a very powerful test tool but the problem
> is that it produces unreadable results. It takes an input
> file executes all the attribute values and throws an
> exception if there is an error. There are about 150+ of these
> files. To fix it up I wrapped it in Junit. Now each executed
> file is treated as an individual test. This works great, I
> have a nice gui telling me which testfiles passed and which failed.
> The problem is that it doesnt tell me why they fail. the
> original program still throws an exception but Junit cannot
> hear it. Is there any way of directing the error to Junit?
> thanks Jonno
